Ti-incorporation enhanced the hydrogenolysis activity and the yield of 1,4-butanediol (1,4-BDO). A catalyst with Si/Ti = 20 afforded erythritol conversion of 94 mol% with 1,4-BDO yield of 32.6 mol% and total BDOs yield of 51.7 mol% at 190 °C, 50 bar H2 and 12 h. For the catalyst with no titanium (Pt/W/SBA-15), a double the time was required to achieve such yield. There observed electronic connectivity amongst Ti, Pt and W. For the catalyst with Si/Ti = 20, a greater amount of interfacial Pt-O-W(Ti) sites with Pt in + 2 oxidation state was present. The enhanced catalytic performance of these catalysts was corresponded to dispersed Pt (that facilitate hydrogen activation and spillover) and acidic interfacial Pt-O-W sites (that promote the adsorption and hydrogenolysis of erythritol to diols). Graphical Abstract Titanium incorporation promoted the erythritol C―O hydrogenolysis activity of Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts. Pt dispersion, acidity, interfacial Pt-O-W centers and electronic contact between metals contributed to the enhancement in the catalytic performance. ga1 Keywords Hydrogenolysis Polyols Erythritol Terminal diol Ti-SBA-15-supported Pt/W catalysts Promotional effect of Ti Biomass conversion Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Biomass conversion over heterogeneous catalysts has been a research topic of high priority as biomass is a potential renewable resource for energy and chemicals (replacing fossils) and valorization of which could lead to net-zero emissions and sustainable development [1–4]. Erythritol (meso-1,2,3,4-butanetetrol) is a C4 sugar alcohol sourced from fruits and fermented food [5]. It is produced mainly via biochemical fermentation from glucose or glycerol [6]. Conversion of erythritol to commercially important C4 molecules like anhydro-erythritol, butanetriols (BTOs), butanediols (BDOs) and butanols (BOs) is a greener approach for their sustainable production which otherwise are made using petrochemicals [7]. Amongst those C4 products, 1,4-butanediol (1,4-BDO) is the most important chemical known for its applications in making butyrolactone, organic solvents, polymers such as polyesters, polyurethanes and polyethers, adhesives, fibers, etc [8]. The major use of 1,4-BDO is in the production of tetrahydrofuran (THF), an intermediate for spandex and other performance polymers. Hydrogenolysis of erythritol is a complex reaction as many C4 products are formed in this process ( Scheme 1). Selective formation of 1,4-BDO through 2°-C―O cleavage of erythritol is a major challenge. The activation energy and acidity of the active sites control the selectivity of the reaction. Bifunctional metal-metal oxides (ReOx/MoOx/WOx promoted supported Ir/Rh/Pt) are promising catalysts for the hydrogenolysis of polyols including erythritol [9]. The nature of metal, metal oxide and support influence the selectivity and activity of the catalyst. Ir-ReOx/SiO2 (4 wt% Ir; Re/Ir mole ratio = 1) showed a maximum erythritol conversion of 74 % with 1,4-BDO and 1,3-BDO selectivity of 33 % and 12 %, respectively at 100 °C, 80 bar H2 and 24 h. H2SO4 addition (H+/Ir = 1) was essential for enhanced stability and activity of this catalyst. The reaction followed a direct hydrogenolysis mechanism wherein the hydride species on the Ir metal attacks the alkoxide species on the ReOx clusters. Added acid enhanced the formation of such alkoxide species [10]. Another study from the same group demonstrated that Ir-ReOx supported on rutile-TiO2 exhibits higher catalytic activity (1,4-BDO productivity = 20 mmol1,4-BDOgIr −1h−1 at 100 °C, 80 bar H2 and 12 h) without mineral acid addition than Ir-ReOx supported on SiO2 [11]. Virgilio et al. [12] had also illustrated that among six Ir/ReOx catalysts with SiO2, Al2O3, activated carbon, CeO2, TiO2 and ZrO2 supports, Ir/ReOx/TiO2 shows highest activity and selectivity providing maximum total BDOs yield of 53 % at 200 °C, 25 bar and 30 h. Small particle size, accessibility to metallic Ir and intimate contact between Ir and ReOx species (Re mainly as Re4+) were the possible factors for the high activity and selectivity to BDOs formation [13]. Rh-ReOx/TiO2 (3.7 wt% Rh; Re/Rh = 0.4) exhibited erythritol conversion of 80% with BTOs and BDOs selectivity of 24 % and 36 %, respectively at the end of 25 h, while Rh-ReOx/ZrO2 (3.7 wt% Rh; Re/Rh = 0.5) provided 82% conversion with BTOs and BDOs selectivity of 28 % and 26 %, respectively in 8 h at 200 °C and 80 bar H2. Support influenced the distribution and reducibility of the Re species [14,15]. Ir-FeOx/rutile-TiO2 (5 wt% Ir; Fe/Ir = 0.25) showed selectivity to 1°-C―O hydrogenolysis product; 2,3-BDO formed with 30 % yield (180 °C, 80 bar H2 and 72 h). The interface between Ir-Fe surface alloy and FeOx particles was proposed the active site. [16]. Ru/ReOx/TiO2 (2 wt% Ru; Re/Ru = 0.9) was another such catalyst which was mainly selective to 2,3-BDO and 1,2-BDO formation (maximum yield of BDOs was 55% at 200 °C, 25 bar and 22 h) [17]. In contrast, MoOx-Pd/TiO2 facilitated removal of vicinal hydroxyls; 1,2-BDO formed with selectivity of 65 % at an erythritol conversion of 26 % (140 °C, 52 bar and 8 h). The selectivity to 1,4-BDO over this catalyst was 21 % only [18]. Pt-WOx/SiO2 (4 wt% Pt and W/Pt = 0.25) demonstrated higher conversion of erythritol and selectivity to 1,4-BDO than Ir-ReOx and Rh-ReOx catalysts. Erythritol conversion of 82.5 % with 1,4-BDO and 1,3-BDO yield of 33.2 % and 10.4 %, respectively was obtained at 140 °C, 80 bar and 24 h. At the end of 50 h, complete conversion of erythritol with 1,4-BDO and 1,3-BDO yield of 51.4 % and 15.1%, respectively was achieved. Reactions at 180 °C yielded mainly BOs, the over-hydrogenolysis products (yield of 1-BO = 56 % and 2-BO = 17 %) [19,20]. Recently, we reported the application of Pt/W/SBA-15 catalysts for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol [21] and erythritol [22]. The SBA-15 catalyst with 4 wt% Pt and 1 wt% W (W/Pt molar ratio = 0.27) enabled erythritol conversion of 82.2% with 1,4-BDO yield of 30.9 % at 190 °C, 50 bar H2 and 24 h [21]. SBA-15 possesses high specific surface area and enables dispersion of Pt and W species on the surface. Tungsten at 1 wt% was present as monomeric / oligomeric WOx species with moderate Brønsted acidity and activates the polyol through its 1°-OH group and promotes the 2 °-C―O hydrogenolysis. Pt nanoparticles (that facilitate dissociative adsorption of H2 and spillover) at 4 wt% loading were in close proximity with the W species. A synergistic enhancement in C―O hydrogenolysis activity was observed on this catalyst composition. Most of the earlier studies required high pressure or long reaction times. More efficient catalysts that are selective to 2 °-C―O hydrogenolysis yielding 1,4-BDO are highly desired. Having noted that TiO2 facilitates communication between the hydrogen dissociating metal and dispersed metal oxide sites through hydrogen spillover, we employed, in this study, Ti-SBA-15 as a support to Pt/W catalysts for polyol hydrogenolysis. Titanosilicates including Ti-SBA-15 have been the widely explored selective oxidation catalysts [23]. They were also employed as acid catalysts [24,25]. Herein, we report, for the first time, the application of Ti-SBA-15 in polyol hydrogenolysis reactions. Ti incorporation into the silica framework retained metal dispersion and improved support-metal interactions and thereby, altered the catalytic performance. A series of Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts (4 wt% Pt; 1 wt% W; Si/Ti molar ratio = 50, 33, 20 and 10) was prepared, characterized and evaluated for C―O hydrogenolysis of erythritol. The effect of Ti-incorporation was studied. Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 catalyst with Si/Ti = 20 enabled highest yield of BDOs (51.7 %) with 1,4-BDO yield of 32.6 % at an erythritol conversion of 94 % in a shorter reaction time (12 h) compared to Pt/W/SBA-15, which required 24 h to get that yield of BDOs at 190 °C and 50 bar H2. Structure-function correlations were also studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Ti-SBA-15 Ti-SBA-15 supports with Si/Ti = 50, 33, 20 and 10 were prepared by the direct hydrothermal synthesis method [26]. In a typical preparation, 4 g of Pluronic P123 tri-block co-polymer (Sigma-Aldrich) was taken in a polypropylene beaker (600 ml) and 30 g of Millipore water and 120 g of aqueous 2 M HCl solution were added to it. The temperature was raised to 40 °C and the contents were stirred for 4 h till the polymer dissolved completely and a clear, transparent solution was obtained. To it, 8.5 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate (Sigma-Aldrich) was added drop-wise over a period of 1 h. Then, a calculated amount of titanium(IV) isopropoxide (Sigma-Aldrich) dissolved in 5 ml of isopropanol was added drop-wise over 0.5 h and stirred for 1 h to get a homogenized solution. Stirring was continued for another 24 h. The gel formed was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (200 ml) and aged at 110 °C for 48 h by placing in an oven. The solid formed was filtered, washed several times with Millipore water, and dried initially at 25 °C for 12 h and then, at 110 °C for additional 12 h. The solid was recovered, ground into powder and calcined in air at 650 °C (ramp rate = 2 °C/min) for 7 h to get Ti-SBA-15. 2.1.2 Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 Tungsten-loaded samples (W/Ti-SBA-15; 1 wt% W) were initially prepared by impregnation method. Then, Pt (4 wt%) was deposited subsequently onto them to get Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15. Ammonium metatungstate hydrate (AMT; (NH4)6H2W12O40.xH2O; Sigma-Aldrich) was used as a tungsten source and tetraammineplatinum(II) nitrate (Sigma-Aldrich) was used as a platinum source. In a typical preparation of W/Ti-SBA-15, 0.0335 g of AMT was dissolved in 100 ml of Millipore water taken in a glass round-bottom flask at 70 °C while stirring for 1 h. Then, it was cooled down to 40 °C and 2.5 g of Ti-SBA-15 was added to it under constant stirring. The suspension was stirred for 24 h at 40 °C. Water in it was removed over a rotary evaporator. The solid obtained was dried in an oven at 110 °C for 12 h and calcined at 450 °C for 4 h (ramp rate = 2 °C /min). It was labeled as W/Ti-SBA-15 (color: white). Then, 0.160 g of tetraammineplatinum(II) nitrate was dissolved in 100 ml of Millipore water taken in a glass round-bottom flask at 40 °C by stirring for 0.5 h. W/Ti-SBA-15 (2 g) was added to it under constant stirring. The suspension was stirred for 24 h at 40 °C. Water was removed over a rotary evaporator. The solid obtained was dried in an oven at 110 °C for 12 h, calcined at 400 °C for 4 h (ramp rate = 2 °C/min) and then, reduced in hydrogen-flow (120 ml/min) at 350 °C for 2.5 h (ramp rate = 5 °C/min). The catalyst, thus obtained was labeled as Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 (color: dark gray). Catalysts were reduced at 350 °C, as the reduction peaks of Pt in temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen occurred below this temperature (vide infra). However, it may be mentioned that we didn’t study the influence of this parameter (reduction temperature) on the metal state and catalytic behavior. For comparison, Pt/Ti-SBA-15 (4 wt% Pt and Si/Ti = 20) was also prepared by impregnating Ti-SBA-15 with the Pt source as described above. Pt/SBA-15 and Pt/W/SBA-15 samples (4 wt% Pt and 1 wt% W) were prepared as reported by us earlier [21]. 2.2 Characterization techniques Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of reduced catalysts were recorded in the 2θ range of 10–80° on a Rigaku Miniflex X-ray diffractometer fitted with a dual goniometer and Cu-Kα radiation source (λ = 0.15406 nm) and operated at 30 kV and 15 mA. Sample to detector distance was ∼333.207 mm. X-ray exposure was 300 s and q-range was 0.0034–0.0946 nm−1. Silver behenate was used to calibrate the instrument. Each sample was subjected to X-ray exposure for a mentioned time. Scattering from Kapton / buffer solution was also collected for the same duration and later subtracted from the profile of individual samples to eliminate the background. Scattering profile of the samples were pre-computed and integrated from 2D image to generate the histogram of intensity versus scattering profile. Nitrogen physisorption studies were performed at − 196 °C on a Micromeritics 3Flex adsorption analyzer. Gas was vented out slowly and the reaction mixture was collected. Each mole of erythritol converted can yield one mole of C4 product (via C―O hydrogenolysis) or one mole of C3 product (glycerol and propane diol(s); via C―C hydrogenolysis and C―C followed with C―O hydrogenolysis, respectively) or one mole of ethylene glycol (via C―C hydrogenolysis of C3 product). Thus, we have adopted calculation of selectivity and yield based on the moles of product formed (not on carbon-based moles). It may be noted that the amount of C4 products formed is significantly higher than the smaller products. The catalyst with Si/Ti = 10 depicted additionally a weak peak at 25.3° attributable to crystalline TiO2 in anatase phase (JCPDS card no. 21–1272). This additional peak was absent for the rest of Ti-SBA-15 catalysts (Si/Ti ≥ 20) and confirms dispersion of titanium in all those catalyst compositions. The catalyst with Si/Ti = 10 contained additionally some amount crystalline TiO2. The XRD peaks due to metallic Pt (JCPDS card no. 65–2868) and WO3 (JCPDS card no. 043–1035) phases were absent and affirmed dispersion of the Pt and W species in all these catalyst samples [30,31]. SAXS studies ( Fig. 1 and Supplementary material - Fig. S2) provided unequivocal evidence for the mesoporous structure of the catalysts by depicting X-ray peaks in the 2θ range of 0.9 – 2.8° indexed to (100), (110), (200), (210) and (300) planes of Ti-SBA-15 possessing 2D hexagonal structure with space group of p6mm [32,33]. The high intensity of (100) peak and well-resolved (110), (200), (210) and (300) peaks (Fig. 1) confirmed the long-range mesopore ordering in these materials. Ti-incorporation did not alter the framework structure of SBA-15 (Supplementary material - Fig. S2). But, a marginal shift in peaks position to lower 2θ values (from 0.99° to 0.90° for the (100) reflection, concluding increase in unit cell parameter (a = 2d100/√3) from 10.3 to 11.3 nm) was noted with increase in Ti content in the catalyst providing evidence for the framework substitution of Ti in Ti-SBA-15 ( Table 1). The ionic radii of Ti (0.061 nm) is larger than that of Si (0.04 nm) and hence, results in an increase in the unit cell size upon framework substitution of Ti (in place of Si) in the SBA-15 structure. Thus, the X-ray studies provided confirmation for the dispersion of Pt and W and framework substitution Ti, apart from enabling evidence for the long-range ordered mesoporous structure of Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts. Mesoporosity of these catalysts was confirmed also with the nitrogen physisorption technique. For the latter catalyst, SBET had increased to 580 m2/g, VTotal had increased to 0.88 cc/g and PD had decreased to 6.6 nm. These changes in textural properties are consistent with Ti4+ substitution for Si4+ in SBA-15. At higher Ti-content of Ti-SBA-15, some amount of Ti4+ is likely to be located also on the surface of mesopores (forming Ti―O―Si and Ti―OH linkages). The textural properties of “neat” SBA-15 (without Pt, W and Ti) are as follows: SBET = 694 m2/g; VTotal = 0.95 cc/g and PD = 7.0 nm. Since the crystallite size of Pt in these catalysts was small (1.8 – 2.0 nm; Table 1), the corresponding peaks in XRD were not detected (Supplementary material - Fig. S1). Elemental mapping (FESEM) was done to understand the spatial distribution of the elements. The presence of Pt, W, Ti, Si and O was confirmed. They were found in close contact with each other. HRTEM provided additional evidence for the hexagonal mesopore structure and uniform one-dimensional pore channel arrangement in these materials. Pt particles (which appeared as black objects in the images) were dispersed and positioned within the mesopores of Ti-SBA-15 ( Fig. 4). The electron diffraction patterns (Supplementary material - Fig. S5(a)) gave evidence for the Pt particles. Additional proof for the presence of Pt, W and Ti elements in the catalyst was gained from energy dispersive X-ray spectrum (Supplementary material - Fig. S5(b)). Considering 125 – 200 particles of Pt located in different regions on Ti-SBA-15, the particle size distribution plots of the catalysts were prepared (Supplementary material - Fig. S6) and the average particle sizes of Pt (PSPt) were determined. With increasing Ti-incorporation up to Si/Ti = 33, the value of PSPt had decreased to 2.1 nm and thereafter, it increased to 2.4–2.6 nm due to changes in Ti speciation (from framework substituted Ti to surface Ti and anatase TiO2; Table 1 and spectral studies vide infra). The CSPt and PSPt values indicated that each Pt particle on Ti-SBA-15 was comprised of about one to two Pt crystallites. The smaller size of Pt particles (PSPt) than the average pore diameter (PD) (Table 1) confirms that these particles were mostly embedded within the mesopores of Ti-SBA-15. CO-chemisorption and HRTEM studies confirmed dispersed Pt nano-particles on Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts. The size of mesoporous channel determined from HRTEM (7–7.8 nm) and from nitrogen physisorption studies (PD = 6.6 – 7.3 nm; Table 1) was comparable. Pore wall thickness estimated from the unit cell parameter (a; SAXS) and pore diameter (PD; N2-physisorption) varied from 3.7 to 4.7 nm. HAADF-STEM inferred that the Pt, W and Ti species were uniformly distributed within the catalysts (Supplementary material - Fig. S7). 3.1.2 Spectral studies FT-IR spectrum of SBA-15 showed a broad asymmetric band in the near-IR region (3000 – 3700 cm−1) with maximum around 3480 cm−1 due to the stretching vibrational modes of surface hydroxyl groups (Si―OH) and adsorbed water molecules. The band due to the bending vibrational mode of water appeared at 1632 cm−1 [35]. Intensities of these bands diminished for Ti-SBA-15 due to reduced concentration of these –OH groups by their condensation with Ti precursor forming Si―O―Ti bonds (Supplementary material, Fig. S8). The characteristic siloxane linkages (―Si―O―Si―) in SBA-15 showed strong bands at 1080 and 1208 cm−1. Anti-symmetric and symmetric stretching vibrational modes of Si―O (νas(Si-O-Si) and νs(Si-O-Si)) appeared at 960 and 805 cm−1, respectively and the bending vibrational mode (δ(Si-O-Si)) appeared at 464 cm−1 [36]. For Ti-SBA-15, the characteristic band of νas(Ti-O-Si) would occur close to 960 cm−1 and it would have overlapped with the band of νas(Si-O-Si). The intensity ratio of FTIR bands at 960 cm−1 and 805 cm−1 (I960/I805) increased with increasing Ti content in Ti-SBA-15 and confirmed the substitution of Ti in silica framework [35]. Pt and W species in the catalysts showed no additional bands (Supplementary material - Fig. S9). DRUV–vis spectroscopy of W/Ti-SBA-15 depicted overlapping bands in the spectral region of 200 – 400 nm ( Fig. 5(a)). The overall intensity of the electronic spectrum increased with increasing Ti content affirming its origin from Ti species. They were the bands arising from ligand-to-metal (O2- → Ti4+) charge transfer transitions [23]. The sample with Si/Ti = 50 showed mainly a band at 210 nm, while the sample with Si/Ti = 33 showed overlapping bands at 210 and 250 nm and those samples with Si/Ti = 20 and 10 showed bands at 210, 250 and 320 nm (Fig. 5(a)). These bands were assigned to the Ti species with different structures. The 210 nm band was associated to isolated Ti species with tetrahedral geometry (TiO4) and the 250 nm band was corresponded to isolated Ti species with penta-/hexa-coordination (TiO3(OH)(OH2)1–2). The 320 nm band was associated to 2D and anatase-type 3D-networked TiO2 species [37,38]. Intensity of the 320 nm band was higher for the sample with Si/Ti = 10 than for the other compositions. Thus, this sample contained higher amount of anatase-type TiO2 species which was detected also by XRD (Supplementary material - Fig. S1). Tungsten would also show charge transfer bands (O2- → W6+) [39]. They must have overlapped with the UV bands of the Ti species. Reduced Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 showed a broad background signal in the region 200 – 800 nm which overlapped with the charge transfer bands of Ti species (Fig. 5(b)). The background signal was corresponded to metallic Pt particles [21]. The XPS of O1s core level of Pt/W/SBA-15 was deconvoluted into two lines corresponding to oxygen in Si-OH and Si-O-Si groups, respectively (Supplementary material - Fig. S10) [40,41]. The former appeared at 534.2 eV and the latter appeared at 533.1 eV. The spectrum of Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 was, however, deconvoluted into three lines assigned to oxygen in Si―OH, Si―O―Si and Si―O―Ti groups (Supplementary material - Fig. S10) and provided further evidence to the presence of Ti in the catalysts. The Ti2p core level spectrum contained 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 spin-orbit doublet lines at 458.7 and 464.4 eV, respectively (Supplementary material - Fig. S11) and confirmed the + 4 oxidation state of Ti species [40]. The XPS lines of Pt0 appeared at 71.4 – 71.7 (for Pt4f7/2) and 74.7 – 75.1 eV (for Pt4f5/2) and those of Pt2+ occurred at 73.3 – 73.8 (for Pt4f7/2) and 75.8 – 77.4 eV (for Pt4f5/2). The marginal shift in B.E. values of Pt4f lines are due to structural and electronic changes (size of Pt particles varied from 2.1 to 2.8 nm and Ti species varied from isolated tetra- or hexa-coordination to anatase-like TiO2). With increasing Ti content in the catalyst, the intensity of Pt2+ lines had increased from 17.1 % to 23.1 %. This change in Pt2+ content could be related to marginal reduction in the size of Pt particles on Ti-SBA-15 supports and higher amount of interfacial Pt―O―Ti(W) sites that contain Pt in oxidized + 2 state. Recall that the particle size of Pt had decreased from 3.3 to 2.1 nm on Ti-incorporation (Table 1). The Pt2+ content was much lower in 4Pt/1 W/SBA-15 than in 4Pt/1 W/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts revealing the influence of Ti on the electronic state of Pt and on Pt―O―Ti(W) interfacial sites and thereby inferring the electronic connectivity amongst Ti, Pt and W. It should also be noted that the presence of Pt2+ can be due to air-contact of the reduced samples during handling which could not be completely avoided. W4f7/2 and W4f5/2 spin-orbit doublet lines of the catalysts appeared at 35.6 – 35.9 and 37.5 – 37.8 eV, respectively and confirmed that the oxidation state of W as + 6 (Fig. 6(b)) [36]. The former two reduction peaks were attributed to weakly and strongly interacting Pt species on SBA-15 [42,43]. The origin of the peak at 695 °C is not clear at present. When tungsten was also present (Pt/W/SBA-15), the reduction peaks of weakly and strongly interacting Pt species shifted to lower temperatures (115 °C and 360 °C) possibly due to electronic interaction between the Pt and W species (Fig. 7). No major shift in Pt reduction peaks position was observed when Ti was also present in the catalyst (Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15; Si/Ti = 20). In general, tungsten oxide shows peaks corresponding to multi-step reductions: (1) WO3 (VI) → WO2.9 (V, VI), (2) WO2.9 (V, VI) → WO2 (IV) and (3) WO2 (IV) → W(0) [36]. These peaks for Pt/W/SBA-15 had resulted a broad asymmetric reduction profile occurring in the temperature of 450 – 700 °C. For Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 (Si/Ti = 20), these reduction peaks of tungsten shifted by about 10–15 °C to higher temperatures due to strong electronic contact between tungsten and Ti species. The reduction peaks of Ti were not discerned from the broad reduction profile. By and large, the TPR study revealed that there existed electronic connectivity between W and Pt/Ti species. Pt in the presence of W/Ti was more easily reducible. Ti-SBA-15 (Si/Ti = 20) displayed a broad reduction profile in the temperature range of 350–850 °C with maximum around 570 °C and W/Ti-SBA-15 showed additionally weak overlapping reduction peaks at 615, 700 and 790 °C due to tungsten (Supplementary material – Fig. S12). Considering these control experiments, we conclude that the broad asymmetric peak above 450 °C for Pt/W/SBA-15 and Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts is due to both W and Ti species. Hydrogen consumption for Pt/SBA-15 below 447 °C was 0.068 mmol/g. This amount is lower than expected (0.205 mmol/g) for 4 wt% platinum loading. It suggests that perhaps not all Pt on SBA-15 had reduced to its zero state at this temperature. It is also possible that some Pt is already in the reduced form prior to the TPR study and thus resulted in lower hydrogen consumption. Pt/W/SBA-15 showed increased hydrogen consumption (0.117 mmol/g) revealing that higher amount of Pt was reduced when tungsten was also present perhaps due to electronic connectivity. Our earlier work [21] points out that Pt has higher dispersion (62 % instead of 24 %) when W was also present. For Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 (Si/Ti = 20), the hydrogen consumption was marginally lower (0.096 mmol/g) than that for Pt/W/SBA-15. According to the XPS study, the former catalyst contained more amount of interfacial unreduced Pt2+ sites than the latter and because of this reason the hydrogen consumption value of Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 is lower than that of Pt/W/SBA-15. Our earlier in situ electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy study revealed that Pt or Pd impregnation enhances the reducibility of titanium in titanosilicates [44,45]. Hydrogen undergoes dissociative adsorption on metallic Pt or Pd sites. Then, hydrogen spills onto Ti (or W) species and facilitate their reduction creating transient catalytic intermediate species (like Ti3+ (or W5+)). In the present set of catalysts, W5+ species could not be detected by XPS as those transient species are perhaps unstable at ambient conditions. By analyzing cumene cracking reaction, a sensitive probe reaction catalyzed typically by Brønsted acid sites, Fan et al. [31] identified the in situ generation of Brønsted acid sites on Pt-WOx/SBA-15 catalysts (with extremely low amount of W as in the present case) under hydrogen flow. The as-synthesized catalysts contained no Brønsted acidity but provided good yield of 1,3-propanediol in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol [31]. 3.1.4 Acidity studies The NH3-TPD profiles of Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 ( Fig. 8) contained an intense asymmetric low-temperature desorption curve composed of three peaks at 115 °C, 190 °C and 295 °C and a high-temperature desorption at 480 °C. The intense peak at 115 °C is due to physisorbed NH3. This peak was observed as the temperature of adsorption and purging with helium was quite low (45 °C). The overlapping peaks at 190 °C and 295 °C are due to weak and moderate strength acid sites on the catalyst. The high temperature peak at 480 °C corresponds to NH3 desorption from strong acid sites [46,47]. For Pt/W/SBA-15, only the former three desorption peaks were observed [21]. The high temperature peak at 480 °C was absent for this sample and confirms that Ti-incorporation creates new type of strong acid sites. 3.2 Catalytic activity Scheme 1 presents the C―O hydrogenolysis products of erythritol. Cleavage of 1°- and 2°-C―O bonds of erythritol yields 1,2,3-butanetriol (1,2,3-BTO) and 1,2,4-butanetriol (1,2,4-BTO), respectively. Further hydrogenolysis of these BTOs yields 2,3-, 1,2-, 1,3- and 1,4-butanediols (2,3-, 1,2-, 1,3-, and 1,4-BDOs). Still further hydrogenolysis of the BDOs leads to 1-butanol (1-BO) and 2-butanol (2-BO). All these hydrogenolysis products are valuable industrial chemicals. But selective hydrogenolysis to 1,4-BDO (terminal diol) is of great demand due to the much higher market value of 1,4-BDO than the other BDOs. Others including glycerol, ethylene glycol, propylene glycols and dehydrated product were also formed in minor quantities along with the above major C―O hydrogenolysis products. Catalysts with higher acidity exhibited higher selectivity to these other products. Control experiments revealed that Pt/SBA-15 was weakly active for this reaction at 190 °C, 50 bar H2 and reaction time of 12 h. It enabled 1,4-BDO with yield of 1.8 mol% only (erythritol conversion = 4.8 mol% and 1,4-BDO selectivity = 37.1 mol%; Table 3, Run No. 1). Selectivity to the other products was 32.5 %. Thus, supported Pt alone is not an active C―O hydrogenolysis catalyst. Pt/W/SBA-15 showed higher activity (than Pt/SBA-15) owing to its bimetallic nature. It showed improved selectivity to BTOs and BDOs. Erythritol conversion of 58.1 mol% and 1,4-BDO yield of 20.2 mol% were obtained at our reaction conditions (Table 3, Run No, 3). The selectivity to total BDOs was around 44.9 mol% and BTOs was 39.6 mol%. Selectivity to others was 5.3 mol% only. The synergistic enhancement in catalytic activity is ought to be the electronic interaction between Pt and W sites as evidenced from XPS and H2-TPR studies [21]. To further promote the catalytic activity, Ti-incorporated SBA-15 catalysts were synthesized with varying Si/Ti molar ratio. Control study revealed that Pt/Ti-SBA-15 was not much active for this reaction. It provided 1,4-BDO yield of 2.0 mol% with erythritol conversion of 4.8 mol% (Table 3, Run No. 2). The selectivity of others over this catalyst was 28.8 mol%. Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 (Si/Ti = 20) containing Pt, W and Ti exhibited remarkably high hydrogenolysis activity. Erythritol conversion of 94.0 mol% and 1,4-BDO selectivity of 34.7 mol% were obtained. The yield of 1,4-BDO was 32.6 mol% (Table 3, Run No. 6). The selectivity to total BDOs was 55.0 mol% and yield was 51.7 mol%. Pt/W/SBA-15, on extending the reaction time to 24 h exhibited erythritol conversion of 82.2 mol% and 1,4-BDO yield of 30.9 mol%. But the trimetallic catalyst (Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15, Si/Ti = 20) achieved such high catalytic conversion at half the reaction time (Table 3, Run No. 6). Thus, supported Pt-W associated with Ti is a superior trimetallic combination to provide improved C―O hydrogenolysis activity. Higher selectivity to 1,2,4-BTO, 1,4-BDO and 1-BO than 1,2,3-BTO and 2-BO confirms that 2°-C―O bond hydrogenolysis is the selective reaction compared to 1°-C―O hydrogenolysis over the SBA-15-supported Pt/W and Pt/W/Ti catalysts. With a view to find optimum Ti-loading, Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts with Si/Ti = 50, 33, 20 and 10 were evaluated (Table 3, Run Nos. 4–7). Erythritol conversion increased with increasing Ti content up to a Si/Ti value of 20. Then, it decreased on further increase in the Ti content to Si/Ti = 10. XRD, DRUV–vis and XPS studies revealed that the Ti-SBA-15 catalysts excluding the one with Si/Ti = 10 contained isolated Ti species. The catalyst with Si/Ti = 10 contained some amount of anatase-type TiO2. Perhaps, this difference in Ti structure is the cause for lower catalytic activity/selectivity of Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 (Si/Ti = 10). To ascertain this, we impregnated Pt/W on TiO2 (P25) and evaluated its catalytic activity at our reaction conditions. This catalyst was less active showing erythritol conversion of 13.5 mol% and provided 1,4-BDO yield of 6.4 mol% only. Thus, this study reveals that titanium-incorporation in SBA-15 promotes the catalytic activity of the supported Pt-W catalyst for the hydrogenolysis of erythritol in the aqueous medium. The amount of Ti content had an influential effect on the catalytic activity. The higher the dispersed Ti content, higher was the erythritol conversion and 1,4-BDO yield. Bulk titania phase adversely affects the hydrogenolysis activity of Pt/W. At our reaction conditions, the amount of BDOs (1,4- + 1,3-) was higher than of BTOs and BOs. To understand the reaction flow based on the data listed in Table 3, we have plotted variation of products (BTOs, BDOs and BOs) selectivity ( Fig. 9(a)) and yield of 1,4-BDO (Fig. 9(b)) with erythritol conversion. The selectivity versus conversion plot (Fig. 9(a)) confirmed that erythritol hydrogenolysis is a consecutive reaction. With increasing erythritol conversion, the selectivity to BTOs decreased continuously while that to BDOs increased, reached a maximum at around 57 % and then, started decreasing and that of BOs showed continuous increase. Thus, BTOs are intermediates in the conversion of erythritol to BDOs. BOs are the over-hydrogenolysis products of BDOs. The yield of 1,4-BDO increased with increasing erythritol conversion (Fig. 9(b)). To check the substrate scope we had conducted C―O hydrogenolysis reaction of glycerol in a 100 ml reactor at 140 °C, 50 bar H2 and reaction time of 12 h (glycerol = 0.75 g, water = 24.25 g and catalyst = 0.625 g). 1,3-Propanediol (1,3-PDO), 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO), 1-propanol (1-PO) and 2-propanol (2-PO) were the products of glycerol hydrogenolysis. The electron-deficient surface state of Pt together with the structural and physicochemical features was attributed to the higher activity of these composite catalysts. Based on the catalytic activity results reported, we have estimated the turnover frequency for some catalysts for this reaction. Further efforts are needed to improve the stability of the catalyst. 3.3 Structure-function correlation Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts demonstrated enhanced C―O hydrogenolysis activity than the monometallic catalyst (Pt/Ti-SBA-15) inferring the essentiality of both Pt and W species in the catalyst. Ti-incorporation promoted the synergy between Pt and W species. The catalysts with Si/Ti = 20 exhibited the highest conversion of erythritol and yield of 1,4-BDO. Pt particles were dispersed in this trimetallic composition (XRD, HAADF-STEM, TEM and DRUV–vis) and the catalyst possessed higher acidity (NH3-TPD). A catalyst with Si/Ti = 10 showed lower activity than the catalyst with Si/Ti = 20 as it contained some crystalline TiO2, thus reveals the importance of dispersion of Ti species in the catalyst. Earlier studies related glycerol hydrogenolysis activity of supported Pt-W catalysts to surface density [51,52], domain size and degree of polymerization of WOx and also to Pt-O-W interfaces and perimeter interface length [53–56]. In the presence of hydrogen and Pt, Hδ+-(WO3)n δ- type Brønsted acid sites were reported to form in situ at reaction conditions that trigger the reaction. Based on our earlier study [21], we had fixed W content as 1 wt%. At this concentration, W was highly dispersed and possessed tetra-coordinated WO4 and oligomeric WOx species with higher degree of surface density and domain size. We observed an inverse correlation for erythritol conversion with the particle size of Pt ( Fig. 10(a)). This structure sensitivity infers that Pt dispersion is an important parameter for high activity. Smaller the particles higher would be the contact of Pt with the W species and higher would be the interface. The strong electronic contact renders oxidized Pt2+ and reduced acidic tungsten (WOxOH) at the periphery of Pt-W. In agreement with this, a plot of Pt2+/Pt0 versus particle size of Pt (Fig. 10(b)) showed higher amount of Pt2+ species as the particle size of Pt on Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 had decreased to 2.4 nm. Any further lowering of particle size had a negative effect. A linear correlation was found for the conversion of erythritol with Pt2+/Pt0 (Fig. 10(c)). Thus, the hydrogenolysis activity increases with increasing ratio of Pt2+/Pt0 and reveals that the Pt2+(HO)OxW centers at the Pt-W periphery as the reaction centers that catalyze the C―O hydrogenolysis reaction of polyols yielding terminal diols. Any deviation from this correlation (Fig. 10) was perhaps due to differences in the structure of Ti in the catalysts. Electronegativity values from thermochemical data vary in the order: Ti < Pt < W [57]. Accordingly, electron transfer occurs from Pt to W at the Pt-W periphery in Pt/W/SBA-15. But, in the Ti-containing Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 catalyst, such electron transfer happens from both Ti and Pt to W at the Ti-Pt-W interface and thereby, creates higher amount of active Pt2+(HO)OxW sites leading to higher hydrogenolysis activity. H2-TPR study confirmed such electron transfer. Also observation of Ti in + 4 and some Pt in + 2 states is in concurrence with this electron transfer. Dispersed metallic Pt nanoparticles facilitate dissociative adsorption of hydrogen. Spillover of hydrogen onto the tungsten oxide species leads to catalytic active sites. Dispersion (CO-chemisorption and HRTEM), close proximity (HAADF-STEM) and electronic contact between Pt and W (H2-TPR) promoted in presence of Ti leads to facile electron transfer from platinum to tungsten oxide species generating acidic interfacial Pt2+(HO)OxW active sites that activate 1°-OH group and facilitate 2°-C―O bond cleavage in the hydrogenolysis of polyols forming terminal diols. As described by Zhu et al. [58], the Lewis acid centers catalyze the 1°-C―O bond hydrogenolysis of polyols. Fig. 11 presents a tentative reaction mechanism and Ti-Pt-W cooperation in 1,4-BDO formation over Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts. Dispersed metallic Pt particles and W in + 6 oxidation states were the precursor species initially present on Ti-SBA-15 pore surface. At reaction conditions, Ptδ+-(WOxOH)n active sites are formed (via electron transfer from Ti and Pt to W) which trigger the hydrogenolysis reaction. At first, erythritol is activated and 2,3,4-trihydroxybutoxide is formed via 1°-OH group binding to the Brønsted acidic WOxOH sites. Then, dissociative adsorption of hydrogen at Pt followed by spillover leads to 1,2,4-BTO formation through 2-C―O bond scission, 2°-carbocation formation, hydride ion shift and hydrolysis reactions. Further such reactions convert 1,2,4-BTO into 1,4-BDO. The cooperation between dispersed Ti, Pt and W drive the hydrogenolysis reaction and selective formation of 1,4-BDO over Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts. 4 Conclusions In summary, C―O hydrogenolysis of erythritol was studied over Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts with 4 wt% Pt, 1 wt% W and Si/Ti = 50, 33, 20 and 10. BTOs (1,2,4- and 1,2,3-), BDOs (1,4- and 1,3-) and BOs (1- and 2-) were the major products in the reaction. Ti-incorporation significantly enhanced the hydrogenolysis activity. Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 showed higher conversion of erythritol and selectivity to BDOs than Pt/W/SBA-15, Pt/Ti-SBA-15 and Pt/SBA-15. The catalyst with Si/Ti = 20 exhibited highest erythritol conversion of 94.0 mol% and BDOs selectivity of 55.0 mol% with 1,4-BDO selectivity of 34.7 mol% at 190 °C, 50 bar H2 and 12 h. Ti-incorporation has retained the dispersion of Pt. These catalysts were acidic. At higher Si/Ti molar ratio (of 10), bulk anatase-type TiO2 species was also present which lowered the catalytic activity. Structure-function correlations showed that for higher catalytic activity, high dispersions of Pt and Ti are required as higher dispersions impart more interfacial electronic contact of Pt with W. The interfacial sites at the periphery are the active sites for erythritol activation and C―O hydrogenolysis. coredata.dc:description: The C―O hydrogenolysis of erythritol was investigated using Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts (4 wt% Pt, 1 wt% W and Si/Ti molar ratio = 50, 33, 20 and 10). Ti-incorporation enhanced the hydrogenolysis activity and the yield of 1,4-butanediol (1,4-BDO). A catalyst with Si/Ti = 20 afforded erythritol conversion of 94 mol% with 1,4-BDO yield of 32.6 mol% and total BDOs yield of 51.7 mol% at 190 °C, 50 bar H2 and 12 h. For the catalyst with no titanium (Pt/W/SBA-15), a double the time was required to achieve such yield. There observed electronic connectivity amongst Ti, Pt and W. For the catalyst with Si/Ti = 20, a greater amount of interfacial Pt-O-W(Ti) sites with Pt in + 2 oxidation state was present. The enhanced catalytic performance of these catalysts was corresponded to dispersed Pt (that facilitate hydrogen activation and spillover) and acidic interfacial Pt-O-W sites (that promote the adsorption and hydrogenolysis of erythritol to diols).
coredata.dc:title: Promoting effect of titanium on C―O hydrogenolysis of erythritol to 1,4-butanediol over Pt/W/Ti-SBA-15 catalysts
